AVIAN INFLUENZA - SOUTH AFRICA (KWAZULU-NATAL)***********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail, a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Disease<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: 15 Jul 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source:  News 24, 15 Jul 2002 [edited]<http://www.news24.com/News24/South_Africa/Gauteng/0,1113,2-7-829_1214040,00.html>Mild avian flu in KZN---------------Johannesburg - A mild form of avian influenza has been diagnosed in poultry in the Camperdown area of KwaZulu-Natal, the SA Poultry Association said.The association said in a statement released in Johannesburg the influenza was only a mild respiratory disease [that] caused a temporary drop in egg production, but poses no threat to humans.The sub-type of the avian influenza has been identified and confirmed by the Avian Virology Laboratory in the United Kingdom as the H6N2 strain."This particular sub-type is not associated with serious disease in poultry and has not been associated with disease in humans," the statement read.South Africa's internationally recognized status as free from the highly virulent form of avian influenza was therefore not affected.The origin of the outbreak in KwaZulu-Natal has not yet been established but was under investigation. The provincial and national Departments of Agriculture would be involved in the attempt to restrict and control the outbreak.The association urged poultry producers who suspected that avian influenza might be present in their flocks to report it to their nearest state veterinarian.******[2]Date: 16 July 2002From: Luiz Jacintho da Silva <ljsilva@sucen.sp.gov.br>Source: Business Day, 16 July 2002 [edited]Avian Influenza Threatens Kwazulu-Natal Poultry Farms-------------------Intensive sero-surveillance of farms and poultry enterprises in the Camperdown district of KwaZulu-Natal is underway following the discovery of Avian influenza in the first outbreak of the disease in southern Africa.The discovery of the virus coincides with reports of recent outbreaks in many parts of the world where it has not occurred before.While veterinary scientists maintain the disease poses no risk to people or poultry products, various strains of it can have a crippling effect on the poultry business. In previous recorded cases in the US, UK, and the Far East entire chicken farms and enterprises have been closed down by the disease.However, according to provincial veterinarian Roger Horner, who diagnosed the virus in tissue from infected chickens just more than 2 weeks ago, the virus affecting chickens in the Camperdown area has been diagnosed as a low pathogenic variety, and it does not give rise to alarming mortality rates.However, Horner warned with 2 local enterprises already suffering a 40 percent reduction in egg production, the disease could have serious economic implications for the local poultry business if it was not contained.Originally called in by local farmers to investigate "something going through the flocks" in the middle of last month, Horner began conducting post-mortems on several chickens. After routine checks for common chicken ailments, Horner began virus isolation on tissue of birds received from 2 poultry enterprises in  the area only to discover the presence of the disease.While subsequent tests, locally and internationally, have revealed this particular strain of virus is not as deadly as that which destroyed poultry businesses in the UK, US, and Far East, SA authorities have yet to learn how it will affect different chickens, in particular commercial layers, broilers, and breeders.The authorities also do not know the extent of the outbreak in the Camperdown district and other parts of the country.The national agriculture department has agreed to finance the necessary testing kits for Avian influenza. The department is conducting surveillance through blood testing on chickens on farms and villages all over Camperdown district. It is being aided in this by farmers and the KwaZulu-Natal  Poultry Institute. Random blood testing in other provinces will be undertaken to see if there are any outbreaks beyond KwaZulu-Natal.Camperdown farmers were advised to practice strict bio-security measures and discourage unannounced visitors.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - USA (West Virginia)      20020512.4184Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & N. SubjectPRO/AH> Foot & mouth disease - UK: formal inquiries (03)
FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - UK: FORMAL INQUIRIES (03)***********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>[1]Date: 18 Jul 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: The Times, 17 Jul 2002 [edited]<http://www.timesonline.co.uk/section/0,,172,00.html>Consumers "must be persuaded that vaccinated beef is safe"----------------------------------------------------------A campaign to promote the safety of meat and milk from animals vaccinated against foot-and-mouth disease was recommended yesterday as a vital weapon to combat any future outbreak. The country's leading scientific establishment, the Royal Society, insists that consumers must be won over if the Government is to adopt a vaccination strategy. As The Times revealed last month, the scientific inquiry backs the use of "ring" vaccination as "major tool of first resort" to prevent any future outbreak becoming an epidemic.Unlike the Dutch experience last year, when vaccinated animals were subsequently slaughtered and banned from human consumption, the inquiry team advocates "vaccinate to live" with animals going normally into the food chain. It is demanding a change of rules throughout the European Union by the end of next year.Sir Brian Follett, chairman of the inquiry, said that the Food Standards Agency had already advised that there were no risks to human health about eating products from vaccinated animals. He added: "I don't know if society can face the alternative." (He was clearly referring to the mass slaughter last year of more than 10 million farm animals.) Ian McConnell, director of research at the Department of Clinical Veterinary Medicine at Cambridge University, said that we already consume products from animals vaccinated against 33 other diseases.Consumer resistance was one of the main reasons for the Government rejecting a vaccination programme last year. Supermarkets were willing to stock vaccinated food but feared labelled products could be left unsold.Sir Brian said such a controversial debate should not take place at the height of an epidemic. Contingency plans for a future outbreak of livestock diseases should be debated in public and agreed by all interested groups including consumers. An emergency drill should be rehearsed each year.The inquiry also criticised the slaughter of animals within a mile of an infected farm. This so-called "contiguous cull" was recommended by scientists who had drawn up worst-case scenarios and forecasts for the disease. David Black, a vet in private practice in Cumbria and a member of the inquiry, said: "We still don't know how 80 percent of farms became infected. The contiguous cull was an attempt to identify infected animals but it was a blunt instrument."The 400 000-pounds inquiry report concludes, however: "For the foreseeable future there is no alternative, when an outbreak occurs, to the rapid culling of diseased animals, and all those that are ... likely to have been infected by them." Sir Brian explained that the inquiry had favoured emergency vaccination because mass culling was ineffective. "Five times in 80 years we have not been able to contain this disease with these methods. So we think, in most cases, we should use vaccination."The inquiry also accepted that the United Kingdom should seek to remain free of the disease without routine vaccination. Within 10 to 15 years, however, a policy of routine vaccination may be possible. Diagnostic tests will first have to be developed to distinguish whether an animal is vaccinated or infected. Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, supported emergency vaccination as an option. "The threat of importing disease is increasing. It is vital that the resources needed to protect our animal populations and native crops and plants keep pace with that."A new early-warning system to alert the country to the potential threat of new animal and human diseases is proposed by the Royal Society inquiry. Bluetongue is a disease of sheep and goats, never yet found in Britain but present in North America, China, Spain, France, Italy and the Balkans "and so might move into Britain." It is fatal in 70 percent of cases. African horse sickness can also affect dogs. Like bluetongue, this disease spreads by midge bites. Avian influenza or fowl plague, always fatal to poultry, was last seen in Britain 10 years ago. In 1997 a lethal strain was transmitted directly from chickens to humans in Hong Kong. All chickens there were slaughtered, a move the report describes as "drastic but wise." Emergency vaccination is used to control an outbreak.[Byline: Valerie Elliott]********[2]Date:18 Jul 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Daily Telegraph, 17 Jul 2002 [edited]<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2002/07/17/nfnm17.xml&sSheet=/news/2002/07/17/ixhome.html>Foot and mouth computer data was inadequate-------------------------------------------Computer models used to formulate policy in last year's foot and mouth epidemic relied on inadequate data, making the contiguous cull a "blunt instrument", the official scientific inquiry into the crisis said yesterday.The Royal Society's report into infectious diseases in livestock commissioned by the Government criticised the reliance on live mathematical modelling, until then unproven in animal epidemics. It also called for emergency vaccination to be used instead of contiguous slaughter and said it was now up to the Government to convince the public and supermarkets that eating vaccinated meat was not a health risk.Prof Sir Brian Follett, inquiry chairman, said Britain should be ready by the end of 2003 to use vaccination as a "major tool of first resort" provided the Government clarified some of the issues surrounding vaccination. He called for research to be stepped up so that reliable prophylactic vaccination could be developed with the aim of stamping out foot and mouth worldwide forever.Sir Brian also said there was "no sense" to the countryside closures last year, estimated to have cost the rural economy between 5 billion and 20 billion pounds. The report recommended that future contingency plans should be decided and debated by Parliament to prevent party political or other interests interfering with the plan's execution during an outbreak.But for many opponents of the contiguous cull, the report will be vindication that the policy was based on false assumptions.While there was "considerable benefit to be gained from understanding" how epidemics spread using computer modelling, the report said "more work is required to refine the existing models and to strengthen their capacity to inform policy".In March 2001, as the Government insisted it was not facing a crisis in the run-up to the election, Prof David King, the Government chief scientist, took over control of handling the outbreak.He called in a team of epidemiologists from Imperial College, London, led by Prof Roy Anderson. Their analysis confirmed that the epidemic was out of control. Prof King's solution, supported by modelling of 2 other teams, was the contiguous cull policy. But yesterday it was condemned by David Black, a veterinary member of the inquiry committee, as a "blunt instrument."We still do not understand how 80 per cent of farms became infected in the last outbreak. We need a lot more work to understand how disease spreads." The report called for a central database to be set up on farms, location of animals, animal movements and the characteristics of diseases.Prof Anderson conceded that the contiguous cull policy adopted as a result of his team's work was crude. "It was a blunt tool but, in the crisis and given the degree to which the disease was spreading, it was unfortunately the only tool available," he said.Lord Moran, who 4 months ago pressed a crucial vote that defeated the animal health Bill, said the report would force the Government to re-examine its Bill. "Part One of the Bill was based entirely on the legitimising and carrying out of mass slaughter," he said. "A re-think is clearly necessary."[Byline: Robert Uhlig]--promed@promedmail.org>[The specific comment of the Inquiry on routine vaccination of List A diseases (which include FMD) as appearing in its summary, says:"Routine vaccination against some of the OIE List A diseases is possible. While there are no overwhelming scientific or economic reasons against this approach being adopted we believe that, at present, the considerable technical problems and the trade implications argue against changing current arrangements.Nevertheless it is clear that the long-term solution is to develop a vaccine against FMD (and other diseases such as classical swine fever) that confers lifelong sterile immunity against all strains of the virus. An international research effort is required to develop such a vaccine".This new approach towards vaccination is far-reaching and in conflict with the traditional UK policy, devoutly followed since the adoption  of the recommendations in the Northumberland Report. The said "Report  of the Committee of Inquiry on Foot-and-Mouth Disease", Parts 1 and 2, published 7 Mar 1969 and 3 Nov 1969, investigated the 1967-8 epidemic and recommended continuation of the non-vaccination, stamping-out policy. More than 2 decades later, in 1991, the same policy was adopted by the EU: discontinuing the annual, preventive vaccination policy performed by most central and southern European countries for decades, generally with very good results (when meticulously performed). This policy change was reflected in the International Animal-Health Code of the OIE. The changed policy had distinct trade impact, excluding countries that decided to continue vaccinations from exporting live ruminants and their unprocessed products to the EU. This led some of them, such as beef-producing countries in South America, to try and adopt also a non-vaccination policy. It will be interesting now to follow possible changes in the EU legislation and the OIE Code. - Mod.AS].[see also:Foot & mouth disease - UK: formal inquiries      20020713.4743Foot & mouth disease - UK: formal inquiries (02) 20020716.4772Foot & mouth disease - UK: vaccination      20020630.4642]...............................as/mhj/pg/dk*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. CAROLINA) (06)****************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Wed 21 Aug 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Meat News, 21 Aug 2002 [edited]<http://www.meatnews.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Article&artNum=3788>End of disease in sight--------------------------Federal agriculture officials say Virginia's worst outbreak of the disease [avian influenza] seems to be coming to an end and they are reducing their control efforts. Since 2 Jul 2002, blood tests on Virginia poultry have all turned up negative for avian flu. In North Carolina and West Virginia, where a small number of flocks tested positive during Virginia's epidemic, no new cases have been reported in more than 2 months. In addition to the negative tests, no new cases of avian influenza have been found in tests of backyard flocks and wild waterfowl such as Canada geese.Nearly 5 million birds from approximately 200 Virginia poultry farms were destroyed in March, April, and May 2002 to control the outbreak. This cost farmers more than USD 140 million. The disease resulted in some countries, such as Mexico and Russia, banning the import of poultry and eggs from Virginia and other states with confirmed avian influenza cases. Avian influenza does not affect humans but is highly contagious in poultry.A USDA task force helped officials speed detection of the virus and ensure that flocks were destroyed within 24 hours of a positive test. Other measures, such as stopping people from making deliveries to quarantined farms, also helped halt the spread, she said. And while cool, wet conditions in March and April 2002 encouraged the spread of the disease, hot and dry weather after that slowed its progression.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[see also:Avian influenza - USA (Pennsylvania)      20020109.3212Avian influenza - USA (Virginia & North Carolina)      20020406.3895Avian Influenza - USA (Virginia & N. VULTURE DIE-OFF - INDIA, PAKISTAN, NEPAL (03)*********************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sat, 12 Oct 2002From: Lindsay Oaks <loaks@vetmed.wsu.edu>In response to the RFI on the vulture die-off in Asia, I can provide some information regarding the situation in Pakistan.The investigation into population declines of the Oriental White-Backed Vulture (_Gyps bengalensis_) in Pakistan is being primarily conducted by the Peregrine Fund, a USA-based conservation organization, and the Ornithology Society of Pakistan, with logistical support from Bahauddin Zakariya University and the and the Pakistani National Council for Conservation of Wildlife. Field studies over the last 2 years in the Punjab Province indicate significant population declines (up to about 80 percent) associated with high adult mortality rates (11-27 percent). Approximately 75 percent of the dead adult vultures have visceral gout, which in birds is due to either primary or secondary renal insufficiency. High rates of gout-associated mortality occur throughout the year, with moderate peaks in the fall and spring, and with occasional mortality clusters.The diagnostic work is primarily being coordinated by myself at Washington State University. To date we have exported and examined the tissue of 35 birds with gout to try and identify the cause of renal disease. Histopathology indicates acute nephrosis and visceral gout, with minimal inflammation and no evidence of chronicity. Most cases have no other significant lesions. Testing for known causes of renal disease and/or acute death in birds have been negative in 33 of the 35 cases: specific causes ruled out include infectious bronchitis virus, avian influenza, toxic levels of arsenic, cadmium, lead, mercury, toxic or deficient levels of copper, iron, manganese, molybdenum, and zinc, organophosphate toxicity, carbamate toxicity, and organochlorine toxicity. Virus isolation, electron microscopy on intestinal contents, and bacteriology have also been negative. The cause of death in the other 2 vultures with gout were infection with _Mycobacterium avium_ and presumptive organophosphate toxicity.Although there is clearly a significant problem with the Pakistani vultures, a cause has not been established. In Pakistan we feel that the epidemiology and laboratory findings are consistent with either a toxic or infectious disease, and currently we maintain both as working hypotheses. Both field work and laboratory investigations are ongoing.Additional information and updates can be found at--J. Lindsay Oaks, D.V.M., Ph.D.Department of Veterinary Microbiology and PathologyWashington State UniversityPullman, WAUSA<loaks@vetmed.wsu.edu>[Many thanks to Lindsay for this important information.- Mod. AS][The loss of vultures is serious and can result in the spread of diseases. ProMED-mail discussed this issue several times and posted on the vulture die-off in India on a couple of occasions (see references). We do not yet know what is killing the vultures. At first no one took it seriously until the death numbers were increasing dramatically. Vultures are very resistant to anthrax and therefore serve as natural sanitation of the disease, particularly in the cases of wild animals or animals that are seldom observed for signs of illness. By taking the deceased vultures out of the country, we may learn what the cause of death is, but we run the risk of spreading the virus or prion or whatever the cause of death is. - Mod.TG][see also:Vulture die-off - India, Pakistan, Nepal (02) 20021014.5552Vulture die-off - India, Pakistan, Nepal: RFI      20021010.55142001----Vulture die-off - India (04) 20010210.02732000----Vulture die-off - India      20000530.0867Vulture die-off - India (02) 20000920.1619Vulture die-off - India (03) 20000922.1637]...............................arn/tg/pg/mpp*##########################################################*ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. AVIAN INFLUENZA - CHINA (HONG KONG) (12)************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Wed, 18 Dec 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: The Star Online, 18 Dec 2002 [edited]<http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2002/12/18/latest/9219HongKong&sec=latest>Hong Kong Officials Find New Case of Bird Flu-------------------------------------------------------------------Health officials said samples from several chickens found dead in a poultry shop on Wed, 18 Dec 2002 tested positive for avian flu in the second outbreak of the viral disease this month.A probe will be conducted to determine whether more than 20 chickens from the retail outlet on Hong Kong's rural Lantau Island had the same strain of virus that once killed 6 people here, authorities said.As a precaution, 60 other birds from the shop were immediately slaughtered, the Food and Environment Hygiene Department said in a statement. Officials also ordered the shop closed Thu, 19 Dec 2002 for disinfecting, it said.Earlier this month, the Hong Kong Jockey Club found 31 dead birds in a park in the center of a horse track. The Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department found 2 geese among the dead birds that tested positive for avian flu.It remained unclear whether the geese contained the deadly H5N1 virus, which crossed over from birds to humans in 1997 and prompted officials to slaughter all 1.4 million chickens in Hong Kong. Officials have since held mass poultry slaughters and imposed stricter hygiene standards on the industry.Many Hong Kong people prefer to buy their poultry live in markets, where chickens are packed into cages as they wait to be slaughtered on the spot so customers can take them home as fresh as possible.--ProMED-mail@promedmail.org>[An early identification of the involved virus strain is crucial for the decision-making process by the veterinary and public health authorities regarding necessary control measures. - Mod.AS][see also:Avian influenza? - China (Hong Kong)      20020203.3475Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (02) 20020206.3492Avian Influenza - China (Hong Kong) (03) 20020209.3516Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (04) 20020210.3527Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (05) 20020220.3593Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (06) 20020224.3627Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (07) 20020305.3694Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (08) 20020405.3890Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (09) 20020418.3979Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (10) 20020526.4324Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (11) 20020530.4362].........................mpp/arn/pg*##########################################################**                                                          **   Please support the 2002 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon!   **        http://www.isid.org/netathon2002.shtml            **                                                          *************************************************************ProMED-mail makes every effort to  verify  the reports  thatare  posted,  but  the  accuracy  and  completeness  of  theinformation,   and  of  any  statements  or  opinions  basedthereon, are not guaranteed. Avian influenza - China (Hong Kong) (13)****************************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Sun, 22 Dec 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: AFP through The Star Online, 22 Dec 2002 [edited]<http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2002/12/22/asia/hkflu&sec=asia> HK closes park after birds die-----------------------------------------------------HONG KONG: Authorities here closed waterfowl ponds in a park after 4 birds were found dead yesterday, a day after officials sought to quell fears over a new outbreak of deadly bird flu.A spokesman for the Leisure and Cultural Services Department said it would close the ponds in Kowloon Park temporarily as a precaution after 4 ducks and a swan were found dead during regular inspections.The dead birds were passed to the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department for diagnostic testing. Preliminary indications were that the birds carried the H5 avian virus.Secretary for health, welfare and food, Yeoh Eng-kiong, said on Fri, 20 Dec 2002, that there was no cause for alarm after 24 dead chickens were found at 4 public markets in the territory."We expect to see sporadic cases, so this is nothing very surprising because in winter, this is the season where the risk is the greatest," Yeoh said.6 people died when avian flu hit Hong Kong in 1997.A strain of the same H5 virus was discovered in dead poultry at a market in Lantau Island on Wednesday.The chickens' deaths come two weeks after 31 dead waterfowl were found in a park in the centre of Shatin racecourse.As a result, all 60 birds in the park were slaughtered and the park was closed until 9 Jan 2003.The most recent outbreak of bird flu occurred in Feb 2002. Although it did not result in any human deaths, 860 000 chickens and other poultry were culled to stop the disease spreading.

INFLUENZA, AVIAN - ITALY: VACCINATION**************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: Tue, 24 Dec 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Midday Express, News from the EU press and Communication Service'smidday briefing, 12 Dec 2002 [Translated from French and edited]<http://europa.eu.int/comm/dgs/health_consumer/library/press/press261_en.pdf>Measures against avian influenza in Italy-------------------------------------------The European Commission has approved today a vaccination programme against avian influenza in the Veneto and Lombardy regions of Northern Italy, and imposed restrictions on the movements of live birds, hatching eggs, table eggs and fresh poultry meat in the said regions.Avian influenza is a highly contagious disease, caused by a virus, affecting birds. There are 2 forms of the virus, a mildly pathogenic and a highly pathogenic strains, both able to cause epidemics. A transformation of one form into the other one may result from mutation of the virus.During an epidemic of the disease in Italy in 1999-2000, 14 million birds died or were killed, with consequent considerable losses to the poultry industry.In October 2002, the presence of a low pathogenic avian influenza  [LPAI] virus was confirmed, within the framework of surveillance activities, in the Veneto and Lombardy regions. The Italian authorities have acted energetically, including the elimination of affected flocks,  in order to stop the propagation of the virus and to prevent its possible mutation into a highly pathogenic variant. The current vaccination is meant to protect the enterprises at risk.A scientific report on avian influenza is available on the internet at the site <http://europa.eu.int/comm/food/fs/sc/scah/outcome_en.html>.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The current outbreak of LPAI in northern Italy was, as reported by SIPA (the Italian section of the World Veterinary Poultry Association), initially serologically detected in mid-October, caused by LPAI type H7N3. Since then, more than 100 foci were reported, of which at least 80 laboratory confirmed (see in the Italian web-site of SIPA, <http://www.patologiaviare.org/ >).The cases have been recorded in 2 adjacent provinces - Brescia (Lombardy region) and Verona (Veneto region).Among the measures adopted by the authorities in both affected regions, as described in a 6 Nov 2002 official report of Italy to the EU, the following may be of interest:1. No restocking of turkey farms2. Movement of hatching eggs, day-old-chicks, ready-to-lay-pullets, poultry for slaughter within and outside both provinces must be authorised3. Serological monitoring of all poultry farms4. Virological monitoring (commercial ELISA test for antigen detection) of turkey farms5. Strict biosecurity measures have been enforced since July this year in both regions.To these measures, vaccination has now been added. It seems that the decision to vaccinate has been taken in view of the continuing spread of the disease. Most countries would not allow vaccinations against HPAI since that might interfere with disease eradication measures, but would allow vaccinations against LPAI.The LPAI vaccines, used in the USA and Italy, are known to be prepared from infective allantoic fluid inactivated by beta-propiolactone or formalin and emulsified with mineral oil. The use of such vaccines in an EU member-country needs the approval of the European Commission. The current official regulation of the LPAI vaccination in Italy (Italian decree N. 0487 of 19 Dec 2002) and the programme of the emergency vaccination, can be seen at <http://www.oevr.org/news/influenza_aviare%202002/f_indice_influenza.htm>Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) is an OIE list A disease; however, LPAI is not reportable and is not included in the OIE lists A nor B diseases. The diagnostic procedures for the determination of the pathogenicity of isolated AI viruses, as well as the requirements from AI vaccines, are specified in the OIE Manual of standards for diagnostic tests and vaccines <http://www.oie.int/eng/normes/mmanual/A_00035.htm>.Whereas all virulent strains isolated so far have been either of the H5 or H7 subtype, most H5 or H7 isolates have been of low virulence. Such was also the LPAI outbreak in the USA (Virginia and North Carolina), earlier thisyear, caused by "low pathogenic H7N2 virus".The methods used for the determination of strain virulence for birds have evolved over recent years with a greater understanding of the molecular basis of pathogenicity, but still primarily involve the inoculation of a minimum of 8 susceptible 4-8-week-old chickens with infectious virus; strains are considered to be highly pathogenic if they cause more than 75 percent mortality within 10 days. However,  in some cases the morbidity and mortality, and subsequent economical losses, caused by LPAI strains in the field, may be significant. -Mod. AVIAN INFLUENZA - CHINA (HONG KONG) (14)**********************************************A ProMED-mail post<http://www.promedmail.org>ProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseases<http://www.isid.org>Date: 28 Dec 2002From: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>Source: Reuters via Swiss info, 28 Dec 2002 [edited]<http://www.swissinfo.org/sen/Swissinfo.html?siteSect=143&sid=1540255>Hong Kong culls chickens to halt "bird flu"------------------------------------------------------------Hong Kong authorities have destroyed 16 000 chickens and stopped imports of the bird from China until New Year's Eve in an effort to prevent a repeat of a fatal "bird flu" which killed 6 people in the city in 1997.The cull was carried out at a poultry farm in northern, rural New Territories, after more than 1000 chickens were found dead there earlier on Sat, 28 Dec 2002.On Friday, a dozen birds tested at the farm in the Ta Kwu Ling area were found to have been infected with avian flu virus, the government said in a statement. A government spokesman also said chicken imports from mainland China would be halted until 31 Dec 2002 so that it could shut a poultry wholesale market for cleansing and disinfection. The infected farm had earlier made deliveries to the market."To minimise the risk on the possible spreading of the virus, we need to thoroughly cleanse the wholesale market to eliminate (any) virus that might exist there," the spokesman said.The cull was the largest since earlier this year when the government slaughtered some 900 000 chickens after the third major bird flu outbreak.The congested territory of 6.8 million people has been hit by 3 major bird flu outbreaks in the last 5 years, each time leading to massive culls.  In 1997 and 2001, Hong Kong's entire chicken population of over one million birds were slaughtered.--ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The following additional data are derived from another news item, Canada.com,  28 Dec 2002,<http://www.canada.com/halifax/story.asp?id=9C04CA3E-F58F-471D-89F1-F51D0E83CB2F>1. The virus was not of the same strain that crossed over into humans and killed 6 people in 1997, officials said.2. Officials from the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department visited 14 nearby farms and found no abnormal deaths among chickens there, it added.3. Earlier Saturday, officials said samples from dead and sick birds found at an urban park earlier this month have tested positive for avian flu.4. Tests showed that 6 of 18 sick birds and 12 of 45 dead ones contracted avian flu, said spokeswoman Suzanne Ho.5. Officials drained and disinfected several ponds at the park last week. The remaining birds have been quarantined and vaccinated against bird flu.6.
